I want to go over the steps involved for polar alignment. To achieve polar alignment with your telescope, follow these steps:  1.  **Find Polaris:** Begin by roughly aligning your telescope mount towards the North Celestial Pole. You can use the outer stars of the Big Dipper to help you locate Polaris, the North Star.  2.  **Level the Tripod:** Make sure your telescope mount's tripod is as level as possible. Many mounts come equipped with a built-in bubble level for this purpose. It is best to level the tripod after it is already pointing north.  3.  **Adjust the Altitude:** Determine your location's latitude and adjust the altitude of your telescope mount to match it. Use the altitude adjustment bolts on your mount for this.  4.  **Position Polaris with an App:** Use a mobile application such as PolarFinder or Polar Scope Align Pro to find the exact position where you need to place Polaris in your polar scope. These apps utilize your phone's GPS to calculate the precise position.  5.  **Adjust the Azimuth:** Use the azimuth adjustment knobs on your mount to move it left or right. While looking through the polar scope, adjust the mount until Polaris is in the correct horizontal position as indicated by your app.  6.  **Finalize the Alignment:** Make final adjustments to the altitude to place Polaris in the exact position shown in the app. Once you are satisfied with the accuracy of the alignment, tighten all the adjustment bolts and knobs.
